newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia launches trade push on India.
newsitem.headline: Australia launches trade push on India.

text.p: Australia on Wednesday launched its biggest overseas trade promotion aimed at India at the start of a 15-month campaign to upgrade ties with South Asia.

Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said the A$6.0 million (US$4.7 million) "Australia India New Horizons" programme was aimed at encouraging trade by correcting outdated Indian perceptions of Australia.

"It will also herald the beginning of a renewed emphasis in the development of Australia's relations with the entire South Asia region, culminating in next year's Year of South Asia initiative," Downer said.
"Throughout 1997, the government will devote considerable efforts to upgrading ties with all countries in South Asia..."
Downer said economic reforms in India since 1991 had resulted in seven percent economic growth in 1995/96, opening up a huge market for Australian companies.

Two-way trade between Australia and India was worth A$1.7 billion in 1995/96 and should double by the year 2000, he said, while Australian investment in India was around A$500 million at the end of 1995 from a "negligible" amount in the early 1990s.
"On current trends India will be amongst Australia's top 10 trading partners within the next three years," Downer said.
Australian exports to India were primarily coal, wool, metals, machinery, transport equipment and other manufactured goods.
But Downer said opportunities existed for Australian trade in financial and educational services, environmental technology, computer software, telecommunications and medical technology.
The trade promotion campaign between October 22 and early December will be staged in six Indian cities and will involve farmers, chefs and musicians as well as business leaders.
